Package remodel.util

Class PureList<T>

java.lang.Object
remodel.util.PureCollection<T>
remodel.util.PureList<T>
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Iterable<T>
public class PureList<T>
extends PureCollection<T>
PureList is the ReMoDeL constructive list type. It supports only constructive operations without side-effects. New lists are created by the methods with(), without(), and append(). The head and tail of the list are accessed using first() and rest(). PureList supports all of the iteration operations that accept Predicate or Function arguments.
Version:
1.0
Author:
Anthony J H Simons

    Creates a singleton PureList containing one element.

  • Constructor Details

    • PureList

      public PureList()
      Creates an empty PureList with an unknown element type. The element type may be inferred from elements supplied later.

    • PureList

      public PureList​(java.lang.Class<?> elemType)
      Creates an empty PureList with the specified element type.
      Parameters:
      elemType - the element type.

    • PureList

      public PureList​(T element)
      Creates a singleton PureList containing one element. The element type of the created PureList is inferred as the type of this element.
      Parameters:
      element - the element.

    • PureList

      public PureList​(PureCollection<T> other)
      Creates a PureList copy of the other PureCollection. The element type of the created PureList is the same as that of the PureCollection.
      Parameters:
      other - another PureCollection collection.

  • Method Details

    • add

      public PureList<T> add​(T element)
      Adds an element (destructively) to this PureList. Adds the element to the underlying collection of elements.
      Overrides:
      add in class PureCollection<T>
      Parameters:
      element - the element to add.
      Returns:
      this PureList.

    • remove

      public PureList<T> remove​(T element)
      Removes an element (destructively) to this PureList. Removes the element from the underlying collection of elements.
      Overrides:
      remove in class PureCollection<T>
      Parameters:
      element - the element to remove.
      Returns:
      this PureList.

    • update

      public PureList<T> update​(Function<T,​T> function)
      Applies an updating function to every element of this PureList, for the sake of its side-effect.
      Overrides:
      update in class PureCollection<T>
      Parameters:
      function - the updating function.
      Returns:
      this PureList.

    • with

      public PureList<T> with​(T element)
      Creates a new PureList containing all the elements of this list, to which the specified element is appended.
      Parameters:
      element - the element to include.
      Returns:
      a PureList of the same type, including the element.

    • without

      public PureList<T> without​(T element)
      Creates a new PureList containing all the elements of this list, except for the first occurrence of the specified element, if present.
      Parameters:
      element - the element to exclude.
      Returns:
      a PureList of the same type, excluding the element.

    • first

      public T first()
      Returns the head, or first element of this PureList. If this PureList is empty, returns null.
      Returns:
      the first element.

    • rest

      public PureList<T> rest()
      Returns the tail, or the rest of this PureList. If this PureList is empty, returns this PureList unchanged.
      Returns:
      a PureList containing all but the first element.

    • append

      public PureList<T> append​(PureCollection<T> other)
      Creates a new PureList by appending the other PureCollection, treated as a list, to this PureList. The element type of the created PureList will be the same as that of this PureList and the PureCollection.
      Parameters:
      other - the other PureCollection.
      Returns:
      the concatenation of this and the other PureCollection, treated as a list.

    • select

      public <S extends T> PureList<S> select​(Predicate<T> predicate)
      Creates a new PureList including only those elements of this list that satisfy a given predicate. The result may be of a more specific type. This supports type down-casting from lists of mixed types. The element type of the result must be inferred.
      Type Parameters:
      S - the more specific type of elements in the result.
      Parameters:
      predicate - the test to apply.
      Returns:
      a PureList of the same, or more specific type, containing elements accepted by the predicate.

    • reject

      public PureList<T> reject​(Predicate<T> predicate)
      Creates a new PureList including only those elements of this list that fail to satisfy a given predicate.
      Parameters:
      predicate - the test to apply.
      Returns:
      a PureList of the same type, containing elements rejected by the predicate.

    • collect

      public <S> PureList<S> collect​(Function<T,​S> function)
      Creates a PureList whose elements are created by applying the specified function to every element of this PureList.
      Type Parameters:
      S - the element type of the resulting PureList.
      Parameters:
      function - the mapping function to apply.
      Returns:
      a PureList containing the range of the function, when applied to this PureList as its domain.

    • collate

      public <S> PureList<S> collate​(Function<T,​PureList<S>> function)
      Creates a PureList whose elements are created by appending the results of applying the specified function to every element of this PureList.
      Type Parameters:
      S - the element type of the resulting PureList.
      Parameters:
      function - the mapping function to apply.
      Returns:
      a PureList containing the distributed appending of the range of the function, when applied to this PureList as its domain.

    • toString

      public java.lang.String toString()
      Returns a pretty-printed String representation of this PureList. The String is of the form: "ElemType[e1, e2, ... en]", where ElemType is the simple name of the element type, and e1..en are the pretty-printed String representation of the elements.
      Overrides:
      toString in class java.lang.Object
